There is no evidence to support the use of topical fluoride toothpastes for preventing dental caries in children.

Multidisciplinary interventions may have a positive effect on the quality of care provided by carers and on the use of medication in nursing homes. Multidisciplinary intervention may also have a negative impact on the number of patients prescribed medication and on medication use. Multidimensional interventions may also reduce the number and quality of medication prescribed. Multisciplinary interventions might also have an effect on patient satisfaction. Multifaceted interventions may be effective in reducing the number or quality of medications prescribed.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of water-based exercise programs for people with moderate to severe residual motor impairment.
The evidence from randomised controlled trials is insufficient to determine whether pharmacological interventions are superior to control in the treatment of sustained AF.

The evidence from the available trials is insufficient to support the use of induction chemotherapy as a first line treatment for chemotherapy-resistant cancer. The evidence from RCTs is insufficient.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific anaesthetic agent for cataract surgery. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, adequately reported randomised controlled trials.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antibiotics for the primary prevention of gram-negative bacilli infection in patients with low ascitic fluid protein levels (<15 g/dL). There is a need for further randomised clinical trials with low-income countries to evaluate the efficacy of antibiotics in preventing gram-positive bacillus infection in cirrhosis.
There is no evidence to support the use of vitamin D supplementation in the treatment of AMD.
Treatment with tranexamic acid immediately before caesarean section reduces the risk of postpartum haemorrhage and the need for transfusion.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any particular sampling technique for cervical screening. The results of this review suggest that there is a small but statistically significant difference between the methods used for cervical smear collection.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of animal derived surfactant preparations for the prevention of RDS in preterm infants.
There is no evidence to support the use of brachytherapy for low-risk prostate cancer.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of laser therapy for treating wounds of SCI patients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any of the adjuvant drugs for the treatment of post-radiation nausea and vomiting. There is a need for further well-designed RCTs to determine the role of adjuvenil treatment in the management of this common and distressing symptom.
Cyclosporine is an effective treatment for the maintenance of remission in patients with severe ulcerative colitis.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of corticosteroids in the treatment of SLE. The available evidence suggests that corticolic steroids may be effective in reducing the number of seizures and improving muscle strength and disability in patients with SLE, but the quality of the evidence is poor. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials to determine the optimal dose and duration of cortical steroids in the management of Sle.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether breast milk expressed by breast pumps is better or worse than breast milk obtained by manual expression. There is a need for further research to determine if breast milk derived by breast pump is better than breast pumps obtained by human expression.

Zinc supplementation in children with persistent diarrhoea significantly reduces the risk of death and morbidity from diarrhoeas. The effect of zinc supplementation on morbidity and growth is modest. The evidence is not strong enough to recommend routine zinc supplementation in the prevention of severe diarrhoeae.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of epidural PCA over IV analgesia in the management of postoperative pain.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of rt-PA for acute limb ischaemic stroke.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of albumin bolus infusion for hypotension in neonates. The results of this review suggest that albumin may be effective in reducing the duration of hypotension and improving arterial blood pressure in those with hypotension. However, the results are based on a small number of small trials with few participants and the results were heterogeneous. Further trials are needed to determine the optimal dose and duration of albumins infusion and to compare albumin with other vasopressor agents.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific antibiotic for the treatment of tinea capitis. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials.

There is no evidence to support the use of mouthrinse as an effective analgesic for postoperative pain relief. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials to determine the efficacy of mouth rinse as an analgesic in the management of postoperative nausea and vomiting.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any particular surgical intervention for the treatment of displaced femoral neck fractures. Further research is needed.

There is evidence that the provision of a clinical pathway to patients following hip and knee arthroplasty reduces the length of stay in hospital and the length and duration of hospital stay in the short term. There is no evidence that this benefit is associated with an increase in the rate of complications or readmissions.
Zinc sulphate is effective in reducing the number of sickle cell crises and improving the quality of life of people with sickle pain. However, the evidence is weak and inconclusive.
There is no evidence to support the use of topical collagen-alginate dressings for diabetic foot ulcers.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of external fixation for the treatment of acute fractures of the humerus in adults. There is insufficient information to support the use or refute internal fixation for acute fractures. There are insufficient data to support any specific type of external or internal fixation.
The evidence from randomised controlled trials is insufficient to determine whether leflunomide treatment is effective in preventing the progression of chronic hand and foot cancer.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of biofeedback for pain management during labour.
There is no evidence to support the use of glatiramer acetate for the treatment of RRMS.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether laparoscopic cholecystectomy is superior to open cholecectomy in terms of pulmonary function, complications, or complications of the two surgical techniques.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether CAHPS information is effective in influencing health care decisions.

The evidence from this review suggests that preoperative chemotherapy is effective in prolonging survival in patients with advanced gastric cancer. However, the quality of the evidence is low due to the small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample size. The results should be interpreted with caution due to poor reporting of the trials, poor quality of reporting and the lack of reporting of adverse events.

The evidence from the included studies was limited. The results suggest that PE is effective in reducing smoking prevalence among high school youth. There is some evidence that PE may be effective in preventing relapse. There was no evidence that any PE intervention is effective for preventing relapse in high school students. There are no studies assessing the effectiveness of PE in preventing smoking in young people.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of facemasks in the management of wheeze in infants. Further research is needed to determine the role of facembolism in the treatment of wheezing infants.
There is no evidence to support the use of galantamine for the treatment of dementia in patients with Alzheimer's disease plus cerebrovascular disease.
Topiramate is effective in reducing migraine frequency and disabling symptoms. However, discontinuation after 12 months is associated with a significant increase in adverse events.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of dietary advice to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events in patients with RA.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of Erigeron in patients with acute ischaemic stroke.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of home-based interventions for improving outcomes for patients with HF after hospital discharge.

The available evidence suggests that a short course of oral anticoagulants (four weeks or less) is more effective than a prolonged course (more than seven weeks) of oral antiplatelet therapy in preventing VTE in patients with DVT. However, the evidence is based on a small number of trials with short follow-up and the quality of the evidence was variable. Further randomised controlled trials with longer follow-ups are needed to confirm the findings of this review.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of hydrotherapy for the treatment of OA.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of EMG for hemiplegic hand function.

Risperidone may be an effective treatment for mania, but its adverse effects are similar to those of other drugs. Its adverse effects profile is similar to that of other commonly used antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, risperidol and risperidine.

The evidence from this review suggests that pancreas tonic acid is an effective short-term treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The effect on glycaemic control was greater than that of placebo, but was not as strong as that of metformin. The long-term effects of pancrean acid on glycemic control and glycaemia control are unknown.

VAS supplementation to mothers after childbirth reduces the risk of neonatal mortality and morbidity in infants born to mothers who are not receiving adequate vitamin A. The effect of VAS supplementation on the risk for neonatal death and morbidities in infants who are receiving VAS is unclear.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of amnioreduction for treating severe twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome at term.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of neuroreflexotherapy for low-back pain.

The available evidence suggests that ketamine is an effective analgesic for cancer patients with metastatic pain. However, the number of patients studied is small and the quality of the evidence is poor. The available evidence is based on a single study with a high risk of bias. More research is needed to assess the efficacy of ketamine in cancer patients.

The evidence from this review suggests that CMHC letters and application materials are effective in reducing appointment no-shows. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was low. Further research is needed to determine the optimal content and delivery methods for CMHC letter and application material.
The evidence from this review suggests that there is no evidence to support or refute the use of shared care for women at low risk of delivery.

Oral anticoagulants are effective in preventing vascular events in patients with transient ischaemic stroke and minor ischaemia. However, the evidence is limited. The effect of oral anticoagenics on mortality and major vascular events is unknown.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of tacrolimus in the treatment of arteriovenous fistula clots.

There is evidence that NBI improves the detection of colorectal adenomatous polyps in colorespiratory endoscopy. The evidence is weak and inconclusive. The results of this review suggest that NII may be associated with a small reduction in the risk of colorem adenoma.
There is no evidence to support the use of oral oxatomide in children with chronic asthma.

The evidence from the included trials is insufficient to determine whether or not equine estrogens are beneficial in the prevention of dementia. The evidence from one trial suggests that equine progestogens may be beneficial in preventing dementia in women with mild cognitive impairment. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with small sample sizes and is not robust. Further research is needed to confirm this finding and to assess whether equine steroids are beneficial or harmful in preventing cognitive decline in dementia.

There is some evidence that oxygen therapy may improve exercise performance in COPD. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small studies with variable quality of life outcomes. The results of this review are limited by the small number and small number available studies. Further research is needed to determine whether oxygen therapy is beneficial for exercise performance and whether it is safe and effective in COPDs.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of oral acyclovir for the prevention of CMV disease in kidney transplant recipients.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of phenobarbitone compared to methadone for the treatment of opioid withdrawal in neonates. There is insufficient data to support its use in the treatment or prevention of withdrawal in infants who are on methadones.
There is no evidence to support the use of ACEi in the prevention of CKD in people with hypertension.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of neurolytic coeliac plexus block for pain relief in patients with cancer.

The evidence from this review suggests that adjuvant chemotherapy with filgrastim and progenitor cell support is superior to chemotherapy with anthracycline alone in terms of overall survival and progression-free survival in women with early stage breast cancer. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with high risk of bias and is insufficient to inform clinical practice. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to confirm these findings.

In children with cough, the use of inhaled salbutamol or beclomethasone significantly reduces the frequency of cough and the need for oral antibiotics in the short term. The use of these agents in children with recurrent cough is associated with a reduction in the frequency and severity of cough. The long-term efficacy of these interventions remains uncertain.
There is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the effects of surgery on children and adolescents. There is a need for further well-designed randomised controlled trials.

Rofecoxib 50 mg is an effective analgesic for acute postoperative pain. The short-term efficacy of rofecox ib is similar to that of commonly used NSAIDs, with a lower risk of gastrointestinal adverse effects. Long-term safety data are lacking.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of dietary interventions to prevent or delay the development of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of prone position for ventilated infants who are unable to be orally fed. Further research is needed to determine whether prone position is beneficial or harmful for ventilating infants who cannot be orally or intravenously fed.

Alarm is effective in reducing the number of wet nights spent in bed and the number wet nights experienced by children. The effect of alarms on wet nights is less clear when compared with desmopressin. The effectiveness of alarms compared with other interventions is unknown.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of cord clamping to prevent the development of anaemia in preterm infants.

Ibuprofen 400 mg is effective in treating moderate to severe postoperative pain. The effect is greater than that of placebo, at least in the short term, and is comparable to that of commonly used analgesics such as naproxen, naproxene, napoleonxime, and naproxens. The difference between 400 mg and 30 mg ibuproen is small, but the difference is clinically significant.

Troleandomycin is effective in reducing the use of inhaled corticosteroids in children with asthma. The clinical benefit of roleandomycin in children is small and is probably due to the increased risk of serious adverse events. The safety profile is acceptable in children and adults with asthma, but the long-term safety profile needs to be evaluated.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of telephonic interventions to improve adherence to PEP. There is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, adequately reported, well-conducted randomised controlled trials to improve the evidence base for this important public health intervention.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of laparoscopic surgery for the treatment of dysmenorrhoea.

The limited evidence available suggests that carbamazepine is an efficacious treatment for partial epilepsy. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The trials included in this review were of short duration and were of poor quality. More randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the efficacy and safety of carbamazenine for partial epileptic seizures.

Lenalidomide is an effective oral treatment for induction of remission in patients with active Crohn's disease. Its adverse events profile is similar to that of its parent compound, thalidomides, with a higher incidence of gastrointestinal side effects. However, the efficacy profile is significantly different from that of thalidomside.

Methadone maintenance therapy reduces the risk of fatal drug overdose and the risk ratio of drug-related deaths among injecting drug users. The evidence is strongest for methadone at doses < 55 mg/day. The effect of methadones at doses greater than 55 mg is less clear.

Doxorubicin is an effective adjuvant chemotherapy for the treatment of patients with soft tissue sarcoma. The optimal dose and duration of doxorubiicin treatment remains unclear. The current evidence base is limited by the small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample sizes. The results of this review suggest that doxorbicin may be useful in combination with other chemotherapy regimens, particularly in the treatment or prevention of recurrence. However, the evidence is based on a small number and the quality of the evidence was variable.

Raloxifene may have a beneficial effect on cardiovascular risk in postmenopausal women. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with short follow-up and is not robust. The evidence is insufficient to recommend the use of raloxifyene as a primary therapy for the prevention of cardiovascular disease in post-menopausal or postmenopause women.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of lignocaine for preventing sore throat after intubation.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of closed kinetic chain training compared with no treatment or other forms of exercise for patellofemoral pain.

Diltiazem is effective in reducing the risk of death and disability in Duchenne's dystrophy. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with short follow-up and the results are not generalisable to all Duchennese's dystrophies. The long-term efficacy of diltiazems remains unknown.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific foot reflexology technique for women with foot oedema. Further research is needed.

Alvimopan appears to be an effective treatment for opioid-induced constipation. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients with a variety of different diagnoses and outcomes. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the efficacy of alvimopAN for the treatment of opioid-related constipation and to assess its safety.
There is no evidence to support the routine preoperative evaluation of patients undergoing cataract surgery for cataracts.

There is no evidence to support the use of any specific surgical intervention for patients undergoing bilateral tonsillectomy. The use of bupivacaine, tonsillar infiltration with 0.25% bupiva, or isotonic saline infusion may reduce pain and may reduce the need for analgesia.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of shoulder strapping for patients with acute hemiplegic stroke. Further research is needed to determine the optimal type and duration of strapping, the optimal position and the optimal timing of strappings, and the effectiveness of different methods of shoulder immobilisation.

The Xpert MTB/RIF assay is more sensitive than the MTD assay for tuberculosis, but less sensitive than both the MTB and the MTC. The Xpert test is associated with a higher proportion of total equivocal results and a lower proportion of false negative results. The sensitivity of the Xpert and MTD tests is similar in terms of overall sensitivity and specificity. The MTB test is also associated with higher rates of false positive results.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antipsychotic drugs as a primary treatment for akathisia. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials.

There is some evidence that providing genetic testing information to women with family history of breast cancer reduces the risk of developing breast cancer and ovarian cancer, but the evidence is not strong enough to recommend routine screening for this condition. There is insufficient evidence to support the use of screening information to reduce the risk for other types of cancer.

The combined oral contraceptive combined with progestogens appears to have a small but statistically significant effect on bone mineral density compared to the combined oral contraceptives alone. The effect of combined oral contraception on bone density is small and probably of limited clinical importance. The combined oral and vaginal contraceptives are effective in preventing osteoporosis.
There is no evidence to support the use of beta-blockers in patients with IC.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of nitric oxide donors for the management of retained placenta.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of maternal presence during anaesthesia to reduce the incidence of emergence agitation.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether thyroid hormone therapy is beneficial or harmful for children with congenital hypothyroidism.

The results of this review suggest that melatonin may be beneficial in the treatment of children and young people with epilepsy and intellectual disability. However, the quality of the evidence is low. The results are based on a small number of small studies with a high risk of bias. The quality of evidence for other interventions is low and the quality is poor. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials to determine the efficacy and safety of melatonin.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of any one intervention for the management of incontinent nursing home residents. Further research is needed.

Atorvastatin appears to be effective in reducing the risk of all-cause mortality and cardiovascular events in patients with IC. The effect of atorvastonatin on walking performance is modest, but may be clinically important. The clinical significance of the observed effect is unclear.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of vertical ramus osteotomy for prognathic mandibles. The use of intraoral vertical ramosotomy is associated with a significant reduction in pain and a significantly shorter recovery time compared with conventional surgery.

The evidence from randomised trials is insufficient to support the routine use of combined hepatitis B vaccines in clinical practice. The use of immune globulin in combination with hepatitis B vaccine may be beneficial in preventing hepatitis B infection, but the evidence is weak.

The available evidence suggests that the use of bupivacaine is associated with a better outcome than morphine sulphate for caesarean section. The use of bupivacane appears to be associated with less nausea and vomiting.

The evidence from this review suggests that initial inhaled corticosteroid therapy is effective in improving lung function in COPD. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of patients studied and the small sample sizes. Further studies are needed to confirm the efficacy and safety of inhaled steroids in COPDs.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific chemotherapy or radiotherapy for treating cystic craniopharyngiomas.

The evidence from the included trials was limited by the small number of women, the short follow-up and the lack of reporting of adverse events. Therefore, no firm conclusions can be drawn regarding the efficacy of GnRH agonists for the treatment of endometriosis.

The evidence from this review suggests that patients who receive written health information are more likely to use an audio-visual intervention than those who are not. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was variable. The quality of evidence for the effectiveness of written health education is low. The evidence for other interventions is even less clear. There is a need for further research to investigate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of written healthcare information interventions.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific splint type or type of splint for CTS. There is a need for further well-designed randomised controlled trials with adequate power to assess the effectiveness of different types of splints.

Cognitive behavioural therapy combined with desipramine is effective in reducing weight gain and improving eating disorder symptoms in people with bulimia nervosa. The effect is larger than the effect of either therapy alone. The clinical significance of this effect is unclear.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antibiotics for the prevention of surgical site infection following abdominal surgery.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of back school as a treatment for subacute LBP.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of DHEA for people with schizophrenia.

The evidence from the available trials is insufficient to determine whether bisphosphonates are beneficial in the prevention of skeletal morbidity in women with breast cancer. There is a need for more well-designed, adequately powered, adequately-powered RCTs to determine bispharmacological interventions for the prevention and treatment of skeletal complications in women treated with hormone-based therapies.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. The small number of patients and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the findings. The results suggest that pentasa is an effective treatment for mild to moderate proctosigmoiditis.

There is evidence that BCNU wafers are effective in prolonging survival in patients with recurrent glioblastoma multiforme. There is no evidence that they are safe or effective in patients who are not receiving chemotherapy.
Nitrous oxide is an effective treatment for acute alcoholic withdrawal symptoms. Its use is associated with fewer adverse effects than placebo, but more vomiting.

The limited evidence available suggests that 2 hours of daily photocoagulation is more effective than 6 hours of continuous photocoage in the treatment of mild amblyopia in children younger than 7 years of age. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with short follow-up periods and is not strong enough to support the routine use of daily patching in this population.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of CIPP in the treatment of infants with hyaline membrane disease. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the role of CIPP in the management of this condition.

Prophylactic antibiotic prophylaxis reduces the risk of SSI in neurosurgical patients undergoing surgery. The evidence is weak and inconclusive. There is a need for further randomised controlled trials with larger sample sizes and longer follow-up.

Hydroxychloroquine may be a steroid sparing agent in asthma. However, the evidence is limited. The small number of studies and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the findings. The use of hydroxychloroquines in asthma cannot be recommended outside randomised controlled trials.

Statins reduce the risk of VTE in both healthy and VTE patients with low-LDL cholesterol levels and VKA. However, the effect is small and the magnitude of the effect may be small. The effect on VTE is likely to be small and probably not clinically important.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the routine use of antiviral prophylaxis in HIV-infected patients with increased CD4+ cell counts to reduce the risk of M. avium complex infection.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of metoprolol for the treatment of intermittent claudication.

The evidence from the trials included in this review is limited. The results suggest that tamoxifen may be beneficial for patients with advanced HCC. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients and the quality of the evidence was poor. The data are insufficient to make any firm conclusions.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of either mechanical or surgical repair of closed fractures of the tibia in adults. Further research is needed to determine the optimal treatment for these fractures.
Nimesulide is effective in reducing symptoms and improving cognitive function in AD. It is associated with a significant increase in adverse events.

There is some evidence that team-based nursing interventions can improve the quality of care provided by nurses in the ICU. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with few participants and is heterogeneous. There is a need for more studies with larger sample sizes and rigorous methodology.

There is no evidence to support the use of any of the agents in the treatment of DKD. The evidence is limited by the small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample sizes. Further trials are needed to assess the effects of these agents on DKD and to assess their effect on patient-important outcomes.

Family therapy may be effective in the treatment of bipolar disorder. However, the evidence is limited. The quality of the available evidence is poor. The results of this review suggest that family therapy may have a positive effect on some aspects of mental state, but the evidence base is limited and the results are based on a small number of studies with heterogeneous participants. Further research is needed to confirm these findings and to assess the effects of family therapy on other important outcomes, such as depression, anxiety, sleep, depression-like symptoms, and satisfaction with life.

The evidence from this review suggests that there is no evidence to support the use of antenatal smoking cessation interventions to improve smoking cessation rates among pregnant women. There is a need for further research to determine whether antenatal interventions are effective and cost-effective.

There is some evidence that educational interventions are effective in reducing pain and disability in people with fibromyalgia. However, the evidence is limited and the results are based on a small number of studies with variable methodological quality. There is a need for more high quality, well-designed, adequately powered, well reported and reported RCTs to confirm the effectiveness of educational interventions for people with chronic pain.

Zuclopenthixol is an antipsychotic drug that is effective in reducing aggression and sedation in people with schizophrenia. Its adverse effects are similar to those of other commonly used antipsychotics, such as risperidone, gabapentin, and risperidine.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of dietary salt reduction for the treatment of asthma. The effect of salt reduction on asthma symptoms and on lung function remains uncertain.
Isodesox is an effective sedative for women undergoing surgery. It is associated with fewer adverse effects than midazolam and is associated less nausea and vomiting.

Acyclovir appears to be effective in preventing or treating herpes zoster ophthalmicus. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of trials and the small sample sizes. The evidence for the efficacy of acyclovir in preventing and treating herpes Zoster ocularus is weak and inconclusive.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of lung recruitment manoeuvres in mechanically ventilated patients with CLD. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the role of lung recruitments in the treatment of CLD, and to assess the safety of these manoeuvres.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of ultrasound guided embryo transfer compared with clinical touch in fresh IVF cycles with hormone replacement.
BDP is effective in the treatment of chronic rhinosinusitis. The short-term efficacy of BDP is not clear. Long-term safety and tolerability of BPD is not known.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of dipyrone for acute tension-type headache.

The evidence from this review suggests that there is some evidence that some nursing interventions, such as dietary advice and written materials, may improve patient-centred care. However, the evidence is limited. Further research is needed to assess the effects of these interventions on patient-focused care and on quality of life.
There is no evidence to support the use of branched-chain amino acids for patients with stable liver cirrhosis and latent encephalopathy.
Antifibrinolytic drugs reduce perioperative blood transfusion requirements in surgery. Tranexamic acid is the most effective antifibrINOlytic drug.
The results of this review suggest that there is no evidence to support the use of adjuvant CT for patients with malignant gliomas.

ARI zenarestat appears to be effective in improving nerve conduction velocity and nerve morphology in diabetic peripheral polyneuropathy. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of patients studied, the small sample size and the short follow-up. Further trials are needed to confirm the efficacy of zenerestat in DPN.

There is evidence that aerobic exercise training is effective in improving physical fitness and improving quality of life in women with breast cancer. There is no evidence that exercise training improves psychological outcomes.

The evidence from this review suggests that family planning interventions can improve the quality of life of people with cancer in their final days. However, the evidence is limited and the quality is not strong. The evidence is also limited by the small number of studies and the heterogeneity of the interventions. Further research is needed to determine the optimal type and content of such interventions.

Levetiracetam is a relatively safe and well tolerated monotherapy drug for the treatment of patients with glioma-related seizures. Its use is associated with a lower risk of adverse events than phenytoin, but a higher risk of serious adverse events.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of exercise for people with RA or OA.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of disulfiram for the treatment of cocaine dependence. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of scopolamine for the treatment of postoperative pain.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of ECMO in the treatment of infants with severe pulmonary hypertension.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of cognitive behavioural therapy for patients with asthma. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, well-conducted randomised controlled trials.

In infants with acute bronchiolitis, the addition of alpha-2 agonists to beta2 agonist therapy significantly improves clinical outcomes compared with beta2-agonists alone. The effect of alpha2 agonism alone on clinical outcomes is not clear. The addition of beta2 adrenergic agonists may be associated with a reduction in the risk of exacerbations requiring rescue medication, but the evidence is weak and inconclusive. The use of alpha 2 agonists in acute bronchiectasis is associated with an increased risk of pneumothorax and a decreased risk of pulmonary interstitial emphysema. The role of alpha and beta2 receptor agonists alone in the treatment
Magnesium therapy is effective in reducing the severity of asthma exacerbations in children and adults with severe asthma.

The evidence from this review suggests that the combination of desogestrel and ethinyl estradiol is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of developing glucose intolerance. The effect of desogaestrel alone is small and probably of no clinical importance. The combination of ethinyl and desoggestrel appears to be associated with no significant difference in glycaemic control.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of honey for the treatment of acute postoperative wound infections. Further research is needed.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether NSAIDs are superior to placebo for treating walking leg pain in PVD.
The evidence from randomised controlled trials is insufficient to support the use of remacemide hydrochloride as an add-on treatment for people with refractory epilepsy.

There is some evidence that educational interventions can improve the outcomes for children with wet nights. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was variable. There is a need for more research to assess the effects of interventions on children's confidence in the knowledge and understanding of wet nights and on the ability to dry.

There is moderate quality evidence that exercise programs are effective in reducing pain and disability in people with knee osteoarthritis. There is moderate evidence that aerobic exercise programs may be effective in decreasing pain and disabling symptoms in people aged 60 years or older. There was moderate quality, but inconclusive evidence that any specific type of exercise program is more effective than another. There are no studies evaluating the effectiveness of individualized exercise programs.

Interferon beta is effective in reducing the risk of MS relapse and improving disability in patients with MS. The clinical effect of interferon in this population is modest, but may be due to the small number of patients studied and the small sample size of the included trials. Interferon has a significant safety profile and is well tolerated.

There is some evidence that cognitive behavioural therapy may improve memory function in people with ADI. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with variable methodological quality and small sample sizes. Further research is needed to confirm the findings and to assess the long-term effects of cognitive behavioural therapies on memory function.

The evidence from the trials included in this review suggests that MTF is a safe and effective nutritional intervention for burn patients. However, the quality of the evidence is low and the quality is variable. The quality of evidence for other interventions is poor. Further research is needed to determine whether MTF has a role in the management of burn wounds.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of CPAP in preterm infants to facilitate the removal of mechanical ventilation. Further research is needed to determine the optimal CPAP strategy.

Colchicine appears to be beneficial in improving serum albumin and bilirubin levels in patients with primary biliary cirrhosis. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients with variable disease states and the quality of the evidence was poor.

Clozapine may be more effective than placebo in the treatment of schizophrenia, but its adverse effects are similar to those of other atypical drugs. Its adverse effects profile is similar to that of typical antipsychotics, with its tendency to induce weight gain and sedation.

Rasburicase may be effective in reducing the risk of cancer-associated hyperuricemia in children with cancer. However, the evidence is limited. The small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample sizes of the included trials limit the generalisability of the results. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm or refute the efficacy of rasburicsase in the treatment of cancer associated hyperuricsemia.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of patient-centred diabetes self-management strategies to reduce amputations. There is a need for further research to assess the effectiveness of patient education and self-care interventions for people with diabetes.
There is no evidence to support the use of surface heparinization of the VVBP circuit in liver transplantation.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of growth hormone therapy in children with chronic renal failure and persistent growth retardation.

There is insufficient evidence to support the routine removal of preterm infants from incubators to their own cribs. Further research is needed to determine whether the practice of early removal from incubator to open cribs is safe and effective.

The evidence from this review suggests that antidepressants are effective in treating anxiety disorders. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The majority of studies were small and of poor methodological quality. The results are based on a small number of studies with small sample sizes and small sample size. There is a need for more well-designed, adequately powered, large scale, double-blinded, placebo-controlled RCTs to confirm the efficacy of antidepressants in the treatment of anxiety disorders in clinical practice.

Music listening may have a positive effect on some aspects of behaviour and on some attitudes and skills in children with ASD. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was low. The quality of evidence was poor. There is a need for more research to evaluate the effects of music listening interventions on behaviour and attitudes in children and adolescents with ASD, particularly in the context of music therapy.
There is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the relative efficacy and safety of olanzapine and haloperidol in treating people with amphetamine psychosis.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether HIV transmission among HIV positive women is increased by heterosexual partners with HIV. There is evidence that HIV transmission may be increased by HIV transmission between HIV positive and HIV negative women with HIV positive partners. There are no studies investigating the impact of HIV transmission on HIV seroprevalence among HIV negative couples with HIV negative partners.

The evidence from this review suggests that interferon is efficacious in treating patients with acute post-transfusion hepatitis C. Interferon may be efficacious for treating patients who have failed to respond to standard treatment, but the evidence is limited. The clinical benefit of interferón in treating acute postfusion HCV is not clear.

Cognitive communication interventions may have a beneficial effect on some aspects of cognitive function in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. However, the evidence is limited. The effect on global impression, global impression of mood, global assessment, global state, global perception, global mood, and global impression are not clear. There is no evidence of a significant effect on other important outcomes such as global assessment and global assessment of global impression.

There is no evidence to support the use of topical orabase for oral lichen planus. There is evidence that topical orabatrin is more effective than topical orabinoids in reducing the severity of symptoms and the duration of the burn. There are no clear benefits of topical corticosteroids in the treatment of oral lichens planus, and topical orabanins are associated with more adverse events.

There is evidence that COPD education and self-management education is effective in reducing hospital readmissions and hospital stay. There is insufficient evidence to support the effectiveness of education on health-related quality of life, health-associated quality of health, health related quality of living, health care costs and health-care utilisation.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of occlusal occlusion in dentistry training to improve the outcomes of patients with craniomandibular disorder.

Statins may reduce the risk of MI and myocardial infarction in patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with high risk of bias. The effect of statins on mortality and on major morbidity is unknown.

The evidence from randomised controlled trials is insufficient to determine whether antenatal vitamin A supplementation during lactation reduces the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV infection.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of occupational therapy as a treatment for upper limb function after stroke. Further research is needed to determine the optimal type and duration of occupational training, the optimal intensity and duration, and the optimal duration of such training.

The available evidence suggests that adjuvant chemotherapy is effective in the treatment of patients with liver metastases. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The trials were small and of poor methodological quality. The results should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of patients and the small sample sizes. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to confirm the findings of this review.

The evidence from this review suggests that the use of a consistent and consistent reporting mechanism for medication errors is effective in reducing the number of reports per week and increasing the quality of reports. The evidence from the review suggests a similar effect for other outcomes, such as hospital readmission rates, patient satisfaction, and hospital readmissions. However, the evidence is limited and the quality and quantity of the evidence was variable. The review did not provide a good estimate of the effect of the use and type of reporting system.

Non-invasive ventilation may be beneficial in mechanically ventilated patients who have failed to extubate and require mechanical ventilation. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with short follow-up and is not strong enough to support the use of NIV in mechanically assisted ventilation. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm or refute the benefits and harms of N-IV in this group of patients.
The evidence from the included studies was limited. There is a need for more research to evaluate the effectiveness of peer support for contraceptive use by women aged 14 to 19 years.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of rapid insulin infusion therapy for women with pre-existing diabetes to improve pregnancy outcomes. Further research is needed to assess the effects of rapid infusion therapy on preterm birth, and to assess its role in the management of pre-eclampsia.

The combination of adjuvant chemotherapy and melphalan plus adjuvenil is superior to melphanol alone in achieving complete response and complete response in women with recurrent ovarian adenocarcinoma. The combination chemotherapy regimen is associated with a higher risk of severe toxicity and a higher incidence of adverse events.

Imipenem is effective in reducing the risk of mortality and morbidity in patients with granulocytopenia. The benefit of imipenems is small and is probably due to the increased risk of adverse events. The clinical importance of this benefit is unclear.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of alpha-human atrial natriuretic peptides in cardiac surgery. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine whether alpha-humans are beneficial in reducing the risk of death or major complications.

The evidence from the single-dose trials included in this review suggests that single intravenous tobramycine is as effective as three or four doses in treating Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in people with cystic fibrosis. The single infusion is associated with a lower risk of pulmonary exacerbations and a higher risk of pneumonia, but the absolute difference in pulmonary exacerbation rate between the two doses is small.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of minilaparotomy for large adnexal cysts.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of probiotics for the treatment of Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhoea. Further research is needed to determine whether probiotics are beneficial in preventing recurrence of Cl. difficilae.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of preoperative oxygen administration to reduce the risk of maternal or neonatal mortality or morbidity during caesarean section.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of baclofen for treating spasticity in MS.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antibiotics for the prevention of infection following distal phalangeal fractures.

In infants with bronchiolitis, nebulisation with inhaled corticosteroids significantly reduces the risk of hospital admission and the risk for pneumonia and mortality compared with saline nebulization alone. In infants with severe broncholitis, the risk is higher with inhaling corticostomy. In children, the benefit of inhaled steroids is small and the benefit is not clear.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any specific method of diagnosis for carotid artery dissection. The results of this review suggest that there is no reliable evidence to guide clinical practice.

In patients with COPD, formoterol is more effective than placebo in improving lung function and reducing symptoms. The effect of formoterols on lung function is similar to that of inhaled corticosteroids, but is less clear when compared with ipratropium. The short-term effects of formerol are similar to those of inhaler-pilocriptine, and the long-term safety profile is similar.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of music or sound therapy for reducing pain during circumcision.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any intervention for pain relief during circumcision. Further research is needed.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute routine chest tube removal and milking.

There is some evidence that community-based antibiotic treatment programmes reduce the prevalence of trachoma in children. There is no evidence that such programmes reduce trachomas in children with normal ocular discharge. There are no studies assessing the effect of community- based antibiotic treatment on the prevalence or severity of tratchoma. There was no evidence of an effect of such programmes on the incidence of other chronic conditions such as asthma, dysentery, and dyskinesia.

The evidence from the included trials is limited. The results suggest that total androgen deprivation is effective in the treatment of patients with advanced prostate cancer. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients and the quality of the evidence was variable. The quality of evidence is poor. The available evidence is insufficient to make any recommendations for clinical practice.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of vaccination for preventing neonatal tetanus.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antiepileptic drugs for partial onset tonic-clonic seizures.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of ACE inhibitors in patients with mild to moderate heart failure.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any specific psychological interventions for anxiety disorders. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, adequately reported randomised controlled trials.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of decaffeinated coffee for people with asthma.
NSAIDs are effective in reducing the risk of developing PD. The effect of NSAIDs on the risk factors for PD is unclear.

The evidence from this review suggests that curcumin is effective in the maintenance of remission in patients with active UC. However, the number of patients included in the trials was small and the quality of the evidence was variable. The results should be interpreted with caution due to the small number of included trials and the small sample size. Further well-designed, adequately powered RCTs are needed to confirm the efficacy of curcumeric supplementation in the management of active UC and to assess its role in the prevention of relapse.

The available evidence suggests that the combination of chemotherapy and surgery is superior to chemoradiation alone for the treatment of DSRCT. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The quality of evidence is limited by the small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample sizes. Further trials are needed to confirm the findings of this review and to assess the effectiveness of combination chemotherapy and bone marrow transplantation for DSR.

The use of a single dose of trimethoprim is effective in treating asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy. The use of multiple doses is not. The number of women who have been treated with a single course is small, and the number of pregnancies lost to follow-up is small. There is no evidence of harm from the use of single doses.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of helmets in the treatment of patients with cardiac arrest. Further research is needed to determine the effectiveness of helmets for patients with acute cardiac arrest who remain unconscious after restoration of spontaneous circulation.

Theophylline is effective in reducing apnea and improving apnea in preterm infants with significant apnea. Theophyllines may be effective in treating apnea at the same time as doxapram. The benefits of theophyllina are modest and may be best used in the context of a well-designed randomised controlled trial.

The evidence from this review suggests that strict antibiotic formulary restriction in patients with common infections is associated with a significant cost saving and improved quality of life. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with variable methodological quality and small sample sizes. Further well-designed studies are needed to confirm these findings.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of ACEi antagonists in acute ischaemic stroke.

The evidence from this review suggests that electronic health promotion interventions may be effective in increasing the uptake of primary care services provided by primary health providers. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was low. The evidence is weak and does not provide sufficient evidence to recommend the use of electronic health promotions as a standard part of primary health care services.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of prophylactic antibiotics in the treatment of complete hydatidiform mole.

The available evidence is insufficient to determine whether corticosteroids are effective in the treatment of GAG. The small number of studies and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the findings. Further well-designed, adequately powered randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the optimal corticolic dose and duration of treatment for GAG, and to assess the effects of corticogenic steroids on muscle strength, function, and quality of life.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. There was no evidence of benefit from any of the herbal medicines reviewed. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials to evaluate the effects of phyllanthus amarus for hepatitis B.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of amniotic membrane transplantation in the treatment of acute ocular burns. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine whether amnio membrane transplant therapy is beneficial in the management of acute OA.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of Knowles pins and plates for the treatment of non-vertebral fractures of the midclavicle in adults.

There is some evidence that reminder cards in medical records can improve adherence to treatment. However, the evidence is weak and comes from a small number of studies with variable quality. Further research is needed to assess the effects of reminder cards on adherence to medication and on patient outcomes.

There is some evidence that relaxation therapy can reduce stress levels in healthcare workers. However, the evidence is based on a small number of studies with variable methodological quality and small sample sizes. The results of the included studies were generally negative and the results of these studies should be interpreted with caution. Further research is needed to determine the optimal type and duration of relaxation therapy, the optimal duration and the optimal setting for a relaxation intervention.
There is no evidence to support the use of intravenous immunoglobulin for myasthenia gravis.

The evidence from the included studies was limited. There was no evidence of a significant difference in the rate of caries between fluoride toothpastes and mouthrinse, and no evidence that fluoride toothpaste was more effective than mouthrines. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, adequately reported, randomised controlled trials to determine the effectiveness of fluoride toothpaint versus mouthrinets for preventing caries.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antibiotics in patients with severe sepsis.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of loxapine succinate as a treatment for schizophrenia.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. The small number of patients and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the findings. The results suggest that laparoscopic surgery is an effective treatment for GOR. However, the evidence is based on a small number and is not robust. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the findings and to assess the long-term effects of laparoscopy.

Caffeine may have a beneficial effect on the short-term outcomes of preterm infants with hypoxaemia. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with short follow-up and the results are not reliable. Further trials are needed to confirm the beneficial effects of caffeine on the long-term outcome of pre term infants with hyperoxaemic seizures.

The evidence from the two included trials is insufficient to determine whether TLH is superior to TAH in terms of survival, quality of life or cost. The results of the one trial comparing TLH with TAH suggest that TLH may be associated with a better quality of Life and a shorter hospital stay, but the evidence is not strong enough to support this conclusion.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of auditory and visual feedback to enhance rehabilitation in Parkinson's disease.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of telephone or face-to-face notification for HIV testing among homeless youth.

There is evidence that arm training is effective in improving function in people with moderate to severe arm weakness. There is no evidence that it improves function in those with low to moderate arm weakness, but the evidence is limited. There are no studies assessing the effectiveness of arm training in people who are at high risk of arm weakness or who are in the subacute phase of rehabilitation.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. The small number of patients and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the results. The results suggest that induction chemotherapy before radiotherapy is associated with a significant improvement in survival in patients with locally advanced NNS. However, the evidence is based on a small number and heterogeneous studies. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to confirm these findings.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of chest physiotherapy in the treatment of acute bronchiolitis.

The evidence from this review suggests that family interventions are effective in reducing the use of illicit drug use among youth aged 15 years and younger. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was variable. There is a need for more research to assess the effectiveness of family interventions for drug use prevention among youth ages 15 years to 25 years.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of TENS in labour and birth.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of BtA for treating spasmodic torticollis.

The available evidence suggests that vitamin D supplementation in people with cystic fibrosis may be beneficial in improving bone mineral density. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with short follow-up and the results are not generalisable to people with other conditions. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm or refute the findings and to assess the effects of vitamin D on bone metabolism in people living with cystitis.
The evidence from the included trials is limited. There is no evidence to support the use of PORT in the treatment of women with stage 1 endometrial cancer.
The evidence from the included trials was limited. There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antibiotics for the treatment of bacteriuria in children.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. There is insufficient evidence to determine whether intrasphincteric botulinum toxin is effective for the treatment of achalasia. Further well designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials are needed.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of occlusal splinting for the treatment of TMD.

The evidence from the two included studies is insufficient to determine whether tubal sterilisation is associated with significant differences in pregnancy outcomes. The two included trials were small and of poor quality. Further research is needed to determine if tubal surgery is associated either with a significant difference in pregnancy or a significant reduction in pregnancy rates.

Harpagophytum extract is effective for treating acute and chronic pain, and may be useful for pain relief in people with chronic conditions such as cancer, cancer, HIV/AIDS, and fibromyalgia. The evidence for chronic pain relief from chronic conditions is less clear, but the evidence for pain reduction from chronic pain from cancer is stronger.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of lactitol for the treatment of children with chronic constipation.

The evidence from the two included studies was limited. The first study showed that the use of depot-only contraceptives was associated with a lower risk of OHSS than the use with progestogen-only contraception. The second study showed no difference between the two types of contraceptive. The use of depots was associated by women with a higher risk of amenorrhoea. The contraceptive methods varied between the studies. The effectiveness of depot progestogens in the treatment of amenorrhea was not assessed.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of surgical sealants to reduce the risk of postoperative air leaks.
In patients with bronchiectasis, the evidence from the included studies was limited. There is no evidence to support the use of inhaled corticosteroids in the treatment of bronchiectomy.

The available evidence suggests that naproxen is an effective analgesic for the treatment of moderate to severe acute postoperative pain. The evidence for the effectiveness of naproxens for the management of severe acute pain is less clear.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of varicocele ligation for unexplained unexplained infertility.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of conservative management for women with preterm birth.
There is currently insufficient evidence to support the use of nebulised terbutaline in children with acute bronchiolitis.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of lactation support for the prevention of pain during blood sampling in term infants. Further research is needed to determine whether lactation supports the prevention or treatment of pain in term newborn infants.

Tight management of hypertension during pregnancy reduces the risk of preterm birth and its complications. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of studies and the small sample sizes. Further research is needed to determine the optimal management of this condition.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of neoprene knee protectors for the treatment of varus deformity of the knee.

There is no evidence to support the use of bisphosphonates in patients with CKD. The use of any bispharmacological intervention for CKD should be restricted to patients with a history of severe disease.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of early physical rehabilitation for Bell's palsy. Further research is needed.

The current evidence suggests that the use of a single dose of AVA vaccine administered intramuscularly is as effective as the use in a variety of doses administered subcutaneously. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of studies and the small sample sizes. The use of AAV in a single injection cannot be recommended at this time.

Cyclosporine is effective in the treatment of active Crohn's disease. The small number of patients included in the trials and the small sample sizes of the included studies limit the generalisability of the results. However, the small number and small sample size of the studies do not exclude a clinically important benefit.

There is insufficient evidence to support the use of MIS in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence. The available evidence suggests that MIS may be effective in the short term, but the long term effects are unknown. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials to determine the long-term effects of MIS.

LMWH is effective in the treatment of VTE in patients with VTE. LMWH is associated with a higher incidence of bleeding complications, including thrombotic complications, and a higher risk of thromboembolism. LMWh is associated significantly more severe than UFH. LM WH is associated more severe bleeding than UH.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of SSRIs in the treatment of SS-induced stuttering attacks.

The available evidence suggests that intravenous quinine is an effective treatment for treating malaria in children with severe malaria. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of studies and the small sample sizes. The optimal dose and duration of administration of intravenous and intramuscular quinines remains unclear.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of patella taping for the treatment of pyloric stenosis.

The evidence from this review suggests that providing outpatient follow-up services to patients with head injury after hospital discharge is associated with a significant reduction in the risk of re-injury, but not a significant decrease in death.

The evidence from the two included trials is insufficient to determine whether the use of progesterone or Zhixue Baotai Decoction is effective in the prevention of threatened abortion. Further research is needed to determine the optimal dose and duration of progestational protection.

Pimobendan may have a beneficial effect on subjective state, arrhythmias and mortality in patients with congestive heart failure. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients with moderate to severe disease. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm the beneficial effects of pimobenden on patients with heart failure and to assess its safety.

There is some evidence that self-care education is effective in reducing pain and disability in patients with chronic low-back pain. There is no evidence that it is effective for patients with low-to-moderate-back-pain. There are no studies that have compared self-help materials with other forms of health promotion.

The evidence from the included trials was limited by the small number of patients, small sample size, and lack of methodological quality. The results suggest that the use of progestogens in the treatment of endometriosis is associated with a significant improvement in amenorrhea and a reduction in the risk of recurrent pain. However, the evidence is based on a small number and the quality of the evidence was variable. The quality of evidence for the use in the management of endo-related pain was poor.

Dexamethasone is effective in treating cerebral malaria. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The trials included in this review were small and of poor quality. The drug is not recommended for treating cerebral malignancies.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. The levothyroxine-free regimen was associated with a significant reduction in the risk of relapse after cessation of thyroid hormone replacement therapy, but the evidence from a subgroup analysis of the pooled data suggests that the effect of levothyroid therapy on the risk for relapse after discontinuation of thyroid hormones is not clear. The evidence from one small trial suggests that thyroid hormone reduction may be associated with an increased risk of adverse events.

Interferon-2b is effective in treating chronic hepatitis B negative virus infection. Interferon is effective for treating liver-related serious adverse events, including hepatocellular carcinoma, and liver-associated infections. Interfenol-2a is effective at treating liver related adverse events.

The evidence from this review suggests that the non-reactogenic vaccine is effective in preventing salmonella typhi fever. The vaccine was more effective than the oral vaccine in preventing all-cause mortality and serious adverse events. The safety profile of the vaccine was good, but the safety profile was not. The non-reactive vaccine was associated with a higher rate of adverse events than the Oral vaccine.

The evidence from the included trials was limited. The majority of trials were small and of poor quality. There is no evidence to support the use of surgery over cytoreduction for recurrent ovarian cancer. The one trial that was included in this review showed that surgery was associated with a reduction in overall mortality compared with complete cytoregery. However, the evidence is based on a small number of small trials with poor quality and the risk of bias was high. Further well-designed RCTs are needed to confirm the findings of this review and to assess the role of surgery versus cytorexia in the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancers.

The limited evidence available suggests that paradoxical therapy may be effective in treating conversion disorder. However, the quality of the evidence is poor. The trials were small, of poor methodological quality and had a high risk of bias. The results should be interpreted with caution as they were based on a small number of studies with few participants and were heterogeneous. Further research is needed to determine the optimal type and duration of treatment, the optimal duration of therapy, the best way to deliver the therapy and to assess the effects of different types of paradoxical interventions.

The evidence from this review suggests that a less intensive maintenance regimen of indinavir and zidovudine is more effective than a combination regimen of both indinaviral and zithrombopurine. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients with relatively low disease activity and is not robust. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to confirm these findings.
There is insufficient evidence to support the routine use of photodynamic therapy in patients with thrombocytopenia.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of any intervention for the treatment of hyperbilirubinaemia in term or near term infants.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of ginseng in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antibiotics in children with acute bronchitis.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antibiotics in COPD exacerbations.

There is evidence that the implementation of OSHA guidelines reduces the risk of trench cave-in injuries. The evidence is stronger for the impact of OSHI and TOSHA on the number of injuries than for the number killed or maimed. There is no evidence that OSHA training or education is effective in reducing the risk. There are insufficient data to draw conclusions about the effect of OSH training or the impact on other safety outcomes.
There is no evidence to support the routine use of EPO for the treatment of chronic renal anemia in dialysis patients.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of fetal scalp EEG in labour to detect hypoxia. Further research is needed to assess the effects of fetal EEG on perinatal outcome.

The available evidence suggests that oral nutritional supplements are effective in reducing mortality and morbidity in patients with chronic malnutrition. However, the evidence is limited and the quality of the evidence was variable. The quality of evidence was poor for all outcomes. The available evidence was based on a small number of studies with short follow-up periods and was heterogeneous. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the optimal duration of treatment and to assess the effects of nutritional supplements on mortality and the morbidity of patients with nutritional deficiency.

The evidence from the two included trials is insufficient to determine whether the use of pneumococcal vaccine in children with sickle cell disease prevents the development of serotype-specific IgG antibodies. The use of vaccine in this population is associated with a reduction in the risk of severe adverse events.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of topical betamethasone for the treatment of nasal polyps in cystic fibrosis.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of nasal intubation for ventilatory support in neonates with severe respiratory distress.
There is no evidence to support the use of Ginkgo biloba for the treatment of dementia.

The evidence from this review suggests that antenatal education is effective in reducing the number of women presenting to antenatal clinics for antenatal care. The evidence from the two included studies was limited by the small number of studies and the small sample sizes. There is a need for more studies with larger sample sizes and more rigorous design.

There is some evidence that educational interventions can improve the quality of life of people with CFS. However, the evidence is limited. There is a need for further research to assess the effectiveness of educational interventions for CFS, particularly in relation to the quality and quantity of educational materials and the duration of follow-up.

There is no evidence to support the use of oral antifibrinolytic drugs for primary femoro-popliteal reconstruction. There is evidence that oral anticoagulants may reduce the risk of death and limb salvage but the evidence is weak and inconclusive. There are no data to support or refute the use in secondary femoro popliteal reconstructions.

The evidence from the included studies was limited. There was insufficient evidence to support the use of nicotine inhalers for smoking cessation. There is a need for further well-designed, adequately powered, high quality randomised controlled trials.
There is no evidence to support the use of omega-3 fatty acids in the treatment of ADHD or hyperactivity.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antibiotics in the prevention of refeeding failure in preterm infants with feeding intolerance.

The available evidence is insufficient to determine whether or not growth hormone therapy is effective in the treatment of short stature in people with X-linked hypophosphatemia. Further research is needed to determine the optimal dose, duration, duration and duration of treatment, and the optimal duration of therapy.

VAS may be beneficial in children with pneumonia. However, the evidence is limited. The trials included in this review were of short duration and of poor quality. Further randomised controlled trials are needed to determine the optimal dose and duration of treatment for children with acute pneumonia.

Imiquimod 5% cream appears to be more effective than placebo in the treatment of patients with Basal cell carcinoma. However, the evidence is based on a small number of patients and the quality of the evidence was poor. The quality of evidence for other topical treatments was poor, and the number of participants in the included trials was small. There is a need for more RCTs to evaluate the efficacy of topical imiquimid 5% in the management of Basal Cell carcinoma, and to compare it with other topical therapies.

The use of antibiotics in children with pneumonia is not recommended. The current evidence suggests that antibiotics are effective in reducing the duration of hospitalisation and mortality in children under five years of age with severe pneumonia.
